awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of High Performance Computing Facilities for Research, Instruction and Outreach
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to build and deploy a high-performance computing cluster to facilitate inter-disciplinary and collaborative research at Wilkes University. The cluster will support a broad range of computationally demanding research efforts including development of algorithms for computational chemistry and materials science, modeling protein folding and misfolding, predicting catastrophic geological events, large-scale analysis of bacterial genomes, and analysis of microwave tomography data for medical imaging, among others.  Each of these projects will yield positive societal impacts including environmental hazard prevention, understanding and preservation of ecosystems, design of new nanomaterials, and detecting and treating diseases.  These projects share the common theme of pattern recognition within large, complex, and noisy datasets and simulations.  Thus, this instrument will enable a collaborative and multi-disciplinary approach for the execution of these projects while enhancing pedagogical activities within the college.  The instrument will be administered so as to provide hands-on training for undergraduate students in modern computational techniques across multiple disciplines. The instrument will be the key piece of a new facility that will ultimately support the scholarship activities of a diverse group of investigators working mainly with first-generation college students as well as outreach activities aimed to inspire and encourage underrepresented groups and girls into scientific careers.

The hybrid architecture of the instrument will simultaneously support data- and memory-intensive projects as well as real-time modeling and visualization.  The primary computational engine, consisting of 8-nodes each possessing 24 computing cores (spanned across 2 processors), 4 commercial grade graphics cards, and 96 GB of RAM, will double as a visualization engine with the aid of virtualization software. This will allow the instrument to perform a variety of computational tasks such as molecular dynamics simulations, medium scale finite element analyses, training of smaller neural networks, performing medium-scale bioinformatics analyses, and MCMC analyses/ Bayesian modelling while enabling collaborative work among faculty and students as well as outreach activities through virtualization and visualization.  Additionally, the cluster will include 4 ultra-high-performance nodes each containing 40 CPU cores, 1.5 TB of RAM, and 2 state-of-the-art GPUs.  These nodes will facilitate extraordinarily demanding calculations such as the training of very large neural networks, simulating molecular systems with hundreds of thousands of atoms, and simultaneous alignment of multiple genomes.  By using a combination of a standard batch queuing system as well as more modern container-based resource allocation schemes, this instrument will serve its ultimate goals of enabling computationally intensive, multi-disciplinary collaborative research at Wilkes University and providing hands-on experience and training for undergraduate students in key skills required for our nation's growing scientific work force.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Since Wilkes is a primarily undergraduate institution (PUI) the instrument was
designed to do more than just scientific research. It is the central piece of the new computational facility: Wilkes Accelerated Research, Learning, and
Outreach Cluster (WARLOC). WARLOC now provides instrumentation, support and a platform to conduct scientific research, create and implement new computational science courses and conduct outreach activities.

Research Activities:

Most of the research projects described in the original proposal are near
completion. Utilization of the facility has expanded beyond the college adding
numerous new projects. Research outcomes so far include:

Submitted publications:

A. Sabouni, S. Noghanian, and A. Kishk, "Novel microwave imaging setup using the elliptic structure" IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters, (submitted 2022)

In preparation:

J. Gubbiotti, T. Smith, D. Greybosh, L. Carey, D. Lucent, S. Chepushtanova.
"Assessing protein-drug affinity with topological data analysis and deep
 learning", In preparation (to be submitted in 2022)

 T. Savitsky, E. Freiss, S. Chepushtanova, D. Lucent "Kinetic and thermodynamic
 modeling of the folding of fluorinated proteins", In preparation (to be submitted 2023)

B. Karimi, R. Lee, J. Schnurr. "Risk Assessment of the Largest Rock Slide
along the Southern Slope of the Shickshinny Mountain", In preparation (to be
submitted 2023)

A. Nazzal, "Analysis of the electronic structure of GeSn alloys using density
functional theory", In preparation (to be submitted in 2022)

 L. Kelleher, Z. Anderson, and C. S. Fortunato, "Understanding the biogeographical patterns of microbial communities within the grassland soils of Northeastern Pennsylvania", In preparation (to be submitted 2023)

H. Castejon, "Mapping the Internal Energy Dissipation Paths in Proteins", Journal of Physical Chemistry B, In preparation (to be submitted 2023)

Conference Presentations:

C. Siggins, TQ. Smith, M. Costello, S. Chepushtanova, D. Lucent. "Predicting
Protein-drug Affinity with Topological Data Analysis and Deep Learning", Eastern
Colleges Scientific Conference, 2021.  This was awarded the best research poster in the field of mathematics and physics award.

L. Kelleher, Z. Anderson, and C. S. Fortunato. "Understanding the biogeographical patterns of microbial communities within the grassland soils of Northeastern Pennsylvania", American Society of Microbiology (ASM) Annual Meeting, 2022

R. Maniskas, M. Khamechi, A. Sabouni, "Small Antenna Design for Drug Delivery in Human Body", IEEE Antenna Propagation International Symposium and URSI, Singapore, 2021.

A. Zedolik and A. Sabouni, “Wireless power transmission system for environmental sensor charging via drone,” IEEE AP-S Symposium on Antennas and Propagation and USNC-URSI Radio Science Conference, Denver, July 2022.

Teaching Activities:


WARLOC has had a big impact in the Science and Engineering curriculum. The instrument is heavily used in Senior Capstone Projects and it has also been incorporated in various existing courses and some new courses have been developed and implemented:

Existing Courses:

BIO330/BEGR430: Bioinformatics
This course has been enhanced by hosting high-quality services and databases
locally such as AlphaFold2 and RossetaFold.

CS 325: Database Management
In this course now students use virtual machines and docker containers to explore a variety of database architectures on large datasets including large non-relational databases.  

GIS 272 Advanced GIS and Remote Sensing
This is a computationally expensive and data-intensive course. In WARLOC, students can now analyze large and complex geographical datasets and produce three-dimensional models of geographical regions. WARLOC  also works in concert with our drone and remote sensing devices to facilitate state-of-the-art training in GIS.

New courses:

CS 398: Data Science and Machine Learning
This course covers the fundamentals of modern data science and machine learning. Emphasis is placed on data handling, featurization, embedding, as well as model performance assessment. WARLOC allows students to perform these tasks.

CS 298/PHY 298: Quantum Computing
This course introduces students to Quantum Computing as the future of high-performance and cloud computing. The course is designed for diverse student backgrounds in order to achieve effective group learning. WARLOC allows students to emulate quantum circuits that would be impossible with lesser computing resources. Some student accomplishments are: Competed in the 2022 QHack Conference and solved 8 challenging quantum programming problems (https://qhack.ai/) Developed SullyQ: Lisp-like functional quantum programming language (https://github.com/TQ-Smith/sullyQ-V1) Won the meme contest (https://www.instagram.com/p/CaGUviMldI6/)!  Built a Minecraft-like quantum computing simulation

Outreach Activities:

Unfortunately, due to the COVID pandemic this activity has been delayed a little. However, the institution is easing restrictions gradually and this year the WARLOC team has launched its first of many planned super-computing outreach activities. In the Women Empowered by Science (WEBS) summer camp, young campers were able to explore WARLOC in virtual reality and use it to build mesmerizing fractal landscapes. Other outreach activities are in various stages of development as well. Some examples include AI awareness activities where students can talk to WARLOC and draw pictures with it (enabled by locally hosting GPT and Stable Diffusion algorithms). Another activity that is nearly ready to launch is one in which students study pharmaceutical science by building and testing drugs in VR. This is accomplished with the Nanome software license and the OpenMM toolkit hosted on WARLOC.


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Henry J Castejon
